div.head: Sand from pulverised rock salt and sand from a minium finely ground on marble
div.ab: After they have been dryly ground & beaten in the mortar, they are ground finely on the marble. I mixed the same quantity of each material, and in order to mix them better, I ground them on the porphyry again, & then filtered this through a double sieve or the sleeve of a shirt. Then, I put them on sheets of paper & stored it on marble in a cellar. In one night, they were both moist enough that there there was no need to dampen them further because rock salt, like all other salts, dissolves in dampness. I molded with this very neatly because both should be quite fine. They need to be moist enough so it can be removed easily.

It does not matter if the sand color is white or yellow. Above all it the sand must be lumped together & much like a precious stone or a stone, & the deeper in the earth one gets it from, the better. The signs of its quality is that it is thus gathered together, that, if the stone is removed as it should be i.e. in the correct way, it forms pieces & lumps together, which demonstrates its capacity for binding, & that it the sand is not too dry.

However, it should crumble in your hands. & the grain must be quite small & fine, & homogeneous. If this sand is not fine enough, you can filter it & grind it up finely either with water, or through a sieve, & when it or on the porphyry. & That way it loses its dryness and becomes greasy & well bound. You can mold it in a box mold or in a noyau without wadding, & try it with lead because, if it does not swell & casts neatly, it will bear out well too. Some say that fatty sands do not work for casting metal that is too hot. Artisans who undertake a big job & who want to save money do not need to crush sand & seek the curious properties of artificial sand; they have more to profit from finding natural sand that has the finest grain possible. & for a small job, they take advantage of finding the finest natural sand they can. For a smaller job, they only filter the sand through the sieve. But those who work on a very small scale crush the sand & grind it finely until it becomes impalpable, because they do not need as much sand.
left-middle Ground wheat makes a tawny-colored powder that is quite fine & quite soft. Once this powder has been mixed, it can mix mold very neatly. Try wheat flour burned in an enclosed fire.
